I enjoyed playing Dragon Age: The Veilguard, but it comes with a set of caveats that echo elements found in the many negative reviews. Such is the nature of this very binary way of reviewing. I'd give it about a 7-8/10 based on fun playing, but within the context of Dragon Age and through a critical lense more like a 5-6/10

This game is best understood when taking into account its troubled development. The original concept for DA:V was scrapped when EA wanted to turn the sequel to Inquisition into a live service game. And that decision, even though it was reversed after Anthem utterly flopped and EA backtracked, reverberated through the final version of DA:V we got since Bioware did not get to start from scratch. 

EA gave them only about a year to remake it into a traditional singleplayer RPG. It ultimately still took 3-4 years, but working with constant short-term extentions limited the scope of what the game could have been. If they had been given the 3-4 years they actually needed upfront, they could have been more ambitious. 

Moving onto the actual game now. Visually speaking it is stunning. There are many, really cool ideas here. But it all feels underutilized. Rarely do these ideas transcend window dressing. That makes sense, since a live service title puts less emphasis on the link between the narrative and visual design. Some areas also look a bit overdone or don't feel like they fit, especially with the older games. It's all a bit too vibrant. The dark fantasy setting of DA:O and DA:2 was reinforced by their oppressive visual style and it worked. Despite the stakes being the highest ever, it doesn't feel like it. The more lighthearted tone of a lot of dialogue also undermines it. This often feels a lot like the Guardians of the Galaxy (the game). That's not to say it can't be enjoyable, because GotG is fantastic, but choosing this route means losing a bit what made Dragon Age stand out.

The narrative also heavily suffered from development choices. Because they lacked time, they went for a very traditional and safe good versus evil story. That contrasts heavily with the older titles where there was a lot more room for grey morality. Or evil in general. I never did it but you could be a blood mage in this franchise once upon a time. There were multiple ways to approach dialogue and choices depending on background. Now backgrounds have no impact whatsoever. More importantly, they fumbled the set-up of Inquisition with Solas, which would have been a very interesting antagonist. He's still involved of course, but a lot less than could've been. Perhaps with more time to write a story...?

World building, which includes companions, factions & other side quests suffers from the same issue of rushed writing to just get something out of the door. The Lords of Fortune have no substance whatsoever and appear to only exist to justify the work they had already put into Rivain-related assets as a backdrop. Minrathous is relegated to Dock Town and everything goes through the Venatori, the subfaction they invented in the last game. Nothing new got explored in the first time we ever come here? The Qun is completely absent, replaced by their military arm that serves as nothing more than goons for the villain. The crows have also been sanitzed. Remember when Zevran talked about being bought as a child slave to be trained as a crow? Where have all the interesting factions gone?

Likely due to time constraints we explore the factions through the companions. Without their quests, the factions have no substance. This is different from the past. You didn't need Oghren or Mynne to experience Orzammar or the Circle in DA:O or Blackwell to experience the Grey Wardens in DA:I. You had faction storylines and companions treated seperately. That's not the case here, with a loss of depth for both as a result. The villains of the subplots were cool, but felt underbaked too.

Another casualty of EA mismanagement were choices, a core pillar of Dragon Age. You have 1 really small choice about 5h into the game. Another big one at the end of Act 1. Then virtually nothing until the final 10h when you're wrapping up all companion stories and the game itself. In fact, the game lacked choices at all because of time constraints and because a live service version didn't need those. So most choices here were shoehorned in late in development to check the box, and most pertain to companions and have no impact on the world. A stark contrast to the legacy of the franchise.

The game also suffers from a flawed design choice. All storylines run at the same time and conclude at the end. Unlike DA:O, where you could go to Redcliffe first and wrap that up before moving on, or the various Acts in DA:2, nothing really gets concluded in the first 50 hours. That introduces a lot of tedium in the bulky middle section of the game. I felt burned out by hour 30, but liked the final 10-20 hours. It's a slow burner. 

All of that said, the gameplay is vastly more enjoyable than any of its predecessors (although it lacks depth). It also runs well, looks fantastic & feels very polished. I did like the companions and their arcs, and there are multiple main story sequences that are genuinly very well done. Weisshaupt & the ending sequence are highlights of the franchise and there a few plot developments at the end that deserve praise too. But it is not enough to salvage the game.

So I'd say the game can be a fun and enjoyable adventure, but with the warning that it's not a slam-dunk success on all fronts, with wasted potential as possibly the final game in (this chapter of ) the franchise (?). 

You can thank out-of-touch EA-executives for that. Special shoutout to braindead EA CEO Andrew Wilson for claiming after release that this game failed commercially because it lacked live service elements. The whole reason it flopped was because of your earlier decision to go for live service & unrealistic deadlines, which kneecapped the potential this game had from the very beginning.

Really and honestly, the game doesn't look or play like Dragon Age. 

It just doesn't. 

However, what IS here is a fun and engaging gameplay and story. 

if you can leave any expectation at the door, you'll have a good time and enjoy the ride. If not, well, it might be better to pass on it, as it really doesn't feel like a follow-up. 

Though, if I'm honest, I've been saying that about every Dragon Age game after Origins/Awakening. 

Neither 2, nor Inquisition felt anything like the previous game(s) so this one being different is, ironically, on brand. 


It IS a fun game, just not as deep or consistent as previous games or stories. Its the Saturday Morning Cartoon version of the original.

Edit: I've put about 3x as much time into the game now as when I wrote the review. Honestly, still really liking it. But going to revise it. Its less Saturday Morning Cartoon, more Marvel Movie. 

Is it as good as Origins? No. But I like it better than 2, and honestly, I like the gameplay more than Inquisition, though I feel Inquisition's story was better. 

One of the things I like about it is the content feels Dense. The game doesn't feel like it wastes my time. 
I have a lot of open world fatigue these days, and playing Veilguard feels rewarding on a moment to moment basis. I don't love all the characters, and some of the areas feel iffy, and the gameplay has some weakpoints, but overall it fits together into a game I'm consistently coming back to and already planning my next playthrough. Something that doesn't happen much these days.

I understand the sentiments behind the criticism for this game, but I personally am enjoying it wholeheartedly - no matter the teenage superhero-based sense of writing and overall black and white good-versus-evil narrative. Origins will always remain the best Dragon Age to date, but there is something to like about all instalments of the series, at least for me.
üü¢ 
The graphics in this game look incredible, both when it comes to character models and viewscapes and landscapes. The sound quality of the sound effects and ambience are overall from 7 to 9 out of 10. The combat in this game diverges from the tactical-oriented micro-managing real-time turn-based combat the previous instalments in the sense that it's mostly an action game now, where the only application of time-oriented tactics is when you open the spell menu to produce chain-combos with your companions. Plainly put, the combat is quite similar to Mass Effect 3, minus the whole shooting and taking cover mechanic. Imagine Dragon's Dogma 2 intertwined with Mass Effect 3 and you get Dragon Age The Veilguard in the sense of combat. 
üü°
The music isn't bad, but it's a bit too superhero-themed, which goes against the said narrative of the first game of the series. The plot and sense of progression is linear, since the game follows a said narrative and isn't an open-world rpg like Inquisition. Specific gamers have specific tastes, so this change of storytelling might not be to everyone's liking.
üî¥
Uneven storytelling writing quality. Specific said lines and moments are mind-jarring, while others - not as much. Sometimes it can even get quite good. Prevalent black-and-white ''good guys save the world from evil'' sense of narrative. Your choices mean literally nothing in this game. Barely any of the choices you've made in Inquisition matter here (which are all handpicked, rather than transferred through a save file, because they are literally the only ''choices'' that bear fruit in Veilguard). Hawke and the Gray Warden protagonist from Origins are simply not relevant to this game, which sucks, even if their arcs are concluded. Dialogue options differ from temperament modality. 1 = ''I agree with you completely!'' 2 = ''I agree with you sarcastically'' 3 = ''I agree with you contemptibly''. Proper roleplaying is simply not possible here due to the lack of adequate variety to the dialogue wheel, unlike the Mass Effect Trilogy (1 and 2 mainly). 

To conclude my personal overview of this game:

If you buy it without it expecting to live up to Origins's standards, then you may not be entirely disappointed by it. If you buy it after finishing a run on Baldur's Gate 3, then buckle your seatbelts towards the grand road of disappointment and boredom ahead of you. If you just want a cool action game, where you can make a pretty prince or princess to kill evil demons as, then this game might just be your cup of tea unironically. Make sure you assess the game for yourself before you buy it, rather than go in blind, and know what your expectations are.

I've been a DA fan for years and have played all the games. The hate this game got at launch was totally unwarranted, in my opinion, and while I don't like everything they did with the game, I'm very happy with what was made. (I actually have hundreds of hours in this game on PS5, but due to circumstances bought it on Steam, too.) 

The graphics gave me pause initially, because I expected something that looked more like Inquisition did, but they grew on me once I gave them a chance. I find the combat incredibly fun and engaging, though I've only played rogues and mages (sorry, warriors are boring). Some of the specializations for each class are better than others, and I've found that there's at least one weak one for each class (both in the sense that the specialization abilities/ultimates actually do less damage than others, but also they're just not as interesting/flashy). That's not a huge issue for me, though, so I don't really care all that much. 

There are certain binary choices that irritate me, just because I'm someone who wants to save everyone if I can, so I wish I was at least given the option to do that if I wanted. That, again, is something I don't hate, however, and is therefore not an issue for my enjoyment. I LOVE the companions, all of them. They feel more alive and real than many of Inquisition's did, more like how DA2's companions did. Some of the romances are better than others, but again, not a dealbreaker. (That's what fanfiction is for.)

TL;DR I love this game! The combat is fun, the characters are interesting, the graphics are pretty to look at, and the story is entertaining. It's not quite the game I wanted or was thinking about for the last 10 years, but I'm happy with it how it is. I only wish it did better so the chance of another one being made was higher.

I loved it. I think it could have been darker and the relationships could have been a little deeper, with more freedom of interaction with them as well. But overall I loved the game and think it was a interesting addition to the storyline of Dragon Age.

The game was enjoyable and fun to play but it was also overly simplistic with basic dialogue and linear exploration. If you're wanting to play something like the old Dragon Age games then you'll be very disappointed. I was glad I played it but I won't be replaying.

Very enjoyable experience overall! The combat was fun and engaging, I loved all the companions, and found the storyline to be relatively solid. 
Finished the game and immediately went in for another playthrough, enjoyed it even more the second time around and noticed lots of little details and foreshadowing I missed the first time.
The writing definitely doesn't quite reach the level of the previous games and does feel a bit clunky at points, especially some of the dialogue. I found the relationships with your companions feel a bit more shallow in this game as well. 
It is far from being the best game in the series (which is obviously DA2), but regardless, it was still highly enjoyable to play.

This is an incredibly smooth action adventure game with some interactions that matter depending on what choices you make. All in all, its a very good story driven game. 

I've been taking my time with all the side missions and this is a game I keep coming back to. Currently playing a rogue on my first play through and will likely do another with a warrior. 

Yes its a departure from the other entries but it still is a really good game and I'm having a lot of fun with it.

Starting with what it does well:

++ This game has some of the best level design I've ever seen. The many different areas look incredible, are very detailed, invite you to explore and set a very fitting mood/atmosphere.

+ Combat is very action oriented and I like it. It feels a lot like God of War, always keeping you on your toes, you need to dodge and parry a lot.

+ Perfect balance between fighting and exploring.

+ Graphics/animation and music/sound/speakers are very good. The intonation of the speakers is sometimes off a bit though.

Now to the bad:

-- Writing. It's 90% just horrible. It get's a bit better the more you progress but this is the first rpg I coudn't stand the dialogue (or the companions) so that I now mostly skip it completely.

-- Companion design. There's one companion (Lucanis) I feel neutral about, maybe I even like him a bit. The rest ist just an annoying, unlikeable and dull bunch of forgettable and uninteresting characters. 

-- "Crafting system" and crafting mats. It's so forced and superflous. Crafting mats are placed literally everywhere and picking them up just destroys the flow of the game. You got an intense and dramatic segment? Be prepared to have crafting mats littering all over the level. It's nothing special finding them, you just run there and press "E" and it becomes an annoying trudge very quickly.

--> I didn't mind the "wokeness" of the game. It was presented by many at release as the worst but besides all characters having a slightly gay touch I can live with it. I will not get used to black dwarfes and elves and the usual forced diversity that just feels unnaturally but I can live with that as well. 

I enjoy the game because it's very well crafted, but the terrible writing just pulls it down into mediocrity.

Talk about a game that‚Äôs massively over-hated, huh? The way people were talking about this game before I started playing it, I assumed anything less than the game pissing in my breakfast cereal, slapping my mother in the face, and melting my PC into molten slag would have been a blessing. Then I sit down to play the game, and the entire thing is just fine? It‚Äôs exactly what a BioWare RPG is, except it‚Äôs also the first BioWare RPG that looks good and is fun to play. Yeah, sorry to the version of you stuck in 2010 who thinks [i]Mass Effect 2[/i] and its love of gluing you to a wall to play a pop-up shooting gallery is the peak of BioWare‚Äôs game design. 

And that‚Äôs sort of the crux of the issue with [i]Veilguard[/i]‚Äôs. People are treating it like it‚Äôs some affront to an old standard of BioWare games and writing. Go look up the cutscene where Shepard and their two companions see Sovereign for the first time and talk to it. This is from the period people consider to be BioWare‚Äôs creative heyday, and the first interaction with Sovereign is considered one of the coolest story points in [i]Mass Effect[/i]. Your companions‚Äô dialogue sounds like it was written (and acted out) by a bored teenager. Sovereign has some cool lines, but it‚Äôs essentially reading off its copy of a generic villain thesaurus. The point is, BioWare games from the studio‚Äôs heyday aren‚Äôt written as well as people like to remember, and [i]Veilguard[/i] isn‚Äôt any worse than that level. Legitimately, the worst it gets is when a few characters say ‚Äúnon-binary‚Äù, which is jarringly out of place in a fantasy game, but let‚Äôs be honest, that‚Äôs all people are really getting mad about here. They‚Äôre just using it as an excuse to dump on [i]Veilguard[/i] when they wouldn‚Äôt do the same for the games they played when they were teenagers because those games didn‚Äôt ‚Äúhave pronouns‚Äù. 

Moving to the gameplay, yeah, it‚Äôs the first BioWare game that‚Äôs actually fun to play. Every game they released feels kind of bad at best and [i]really[/i] bad at worst. Seriously, it‚Äôs wild to know that [i]Mass Effect[/i] came out in the same year as [i]Halo 3[/i] and [i]Mass Effect 2[/i] came out in the same year as [i]God of War III[/i]. It really puts into perspective how far behind BioWare had been when it came to making video games that felt fun and interesting to play. While other studios that made fun games were generally able to catch up to‚Äîand often surpass‚ÄîBioWare in writing quality, BioWare struggled to beef up its biggest development weaknesses. 

That issue that‚Äôs been spanning decades has finally been addressed in [i]Veilguard[/i]. The combat is fun, flashy, and has simple enough combos that it doesn‚Äôt feel like I‚Äôve suddenly been transported to playing [i]Street Fighter[/i]. The game‚Äôs primers and detonators work well, and my AI companions were always great about setting up primers. It all flows in combat well. Even pausing the game to pull up your companions‚Äô abilities didn‚Äôt feel like it pumped the brakes too much, and with the token attempt at ‚Äúsquad management‚Äù that had been an annoying ‚Äúfeature‚Äù in past BioWare games pleasantly gone in [i]Veilguard[/i], it doesn‚Äôt feel like I have to babysit what my companions are doing every few seconds. 

Another thing I‚Äôm glad they moved away from is the weird, semi-open world design from [i]Inquisition[/i]. Those semi-open world environments made the game feel like sections were cut out of an MMO and placed into a [i]Dragon Age[/i] RPG. They always felt weirdly empty with their enemies barely scattered around huge swaths of nothing. It felt like BioWare was pressured to take advantage of the new console hardware at the time, and the result was a bit of a boring, sloppy mess. 

[i]Veilguard[/i]‚Äôs areas can feel a little disconnected from each other thanks to the game‚Äôs hub-and-spoke design, but functionally, it‚Äôs not any different than a forest biome magically turning into a snow biome like most other games. While they feel disconnected from each other, each area is richly detailed and pretty to look at, with plenty of loot to find tucked away in some hidden chests. Whether that loot is any good is a matter solely determined by the gods, and it was a little disappointing whenever I went out of my way to unlock a chest full of garbage. As someone who goes out of his way to look for secrets and engage with side content in a game, this gradually gets more and more annoying since most of the gear I was finding wasn‚Äôt better than what I already had. 

While some of the side content irked me, the story does its job. You accidentally release a pair of gods, those gods want to cover the world in goop and tentacles, and you‚Äôd rather they didn‚Äôt do that. One thing I appreciate is that the player character, Rook, is essentially just a normal dude who horrendously botched a mission they were hired to do. This, apparently, means Rook is completely responsible for the fate of the world. You gather your party of characters gradually through the game, which is pretty standard for a BioWare RPG. 

The companions were all fine. They all have their own distinct voices, which is a testament to solid characterization that‚Äôs unique to all of them. As anyone who has played a BioWare RPG would expect, they have their own side quests that flesh them out more, and I appreciate that they‚Äôre not fully spilling their life stories right out of the gate like in [i]Mass Effect: Andromeda[/i]. More importantly, I was interested in their backstories and how their quests ran parallel to the main story. 

Actually, I [i]really[/i] liked how that part of the questing was structured. You aren‚Äôt blasted with ongoing side quests and content right out of the gate. Those quests unlock gradually as you progress through the main story, which makes them move alongside the main story at a reasonable clip. Instead of being able to blitz through a side character‚Äôs story in a few hours, leaving them feeling like they‚Äôre hanging off the overarching narrative, they sort of move along with the overarching narrative, which helps everything feel a little bit more connected together instead of multiple quest lines feeling like they‚Äôre happening in a vacuum. 

The game‚Äôs an easy enough recommendation at the end of the day. It certainly wouldn‚Äôt have broken my top games of the year in 2024, but it wasn‚Äôt anywhere near [i]Black Myth: Wukong[/i], which was the miserable low for the year. [i]Veilguard[/i] ticks all the boxes it needs to be competent across nearly every level of design, but is also almost remarkably unsexy and doesn‚Äôt push any boundaries whatsoever.

I started playing this game with a lot of apprehension because of the criticism it received, so perhaps it was because I expected the worst and didn't get it that made me actually enjoy the game quite a bit. 

First, here is what didn't work:
1) A lot of the exploring is soft locked until later in the story when you get specific quests. In itself, that's a great idea, because it means that even regions you've already been to feel fresh and exciting until the very end of the game. My gripe is very specific. WHY show me chests and collectibles that I cannot obtain until much later in the story on the map? With so many puzzles in the game, it is reasonable to assume as a player that if something is locked behind a barrier of some sort, perhaps you simply have to figure out how to get rid of that barrier. And in about half the cases that's true, so it doesn't really help that when it isn't, I wasted a good 20 minutes on trying to get to a chest, only to give up and be given access 10 hous later. This might not be a major complaint for most, but I'm a completionist and this was extremely annoying to me. 

2) The storytelling has some major problems. 
First of - the main story isn't the issue, it's fine. Like all DA games, it's about saving the world from a terrible, magic and mystery induced evil. Problems only arise when you zoom way in.
 
Bad Dialogue: You mostly have three dialogue options a la Dragon Age 2. But while all of the dialogue options were pretty well written in that game, in this game I can only described some of the lines you get with the "funny" dialogue choice as deeply millenial and painfully unfunny. When it isn't that, the "positive" options sometimes make me feel therapy talk. 
Shoutout in this regard to Bellara, who is just the amalgamation of every "quirky neurodivergent girl" stereotype, (call is coming from inside the house).

Which leads me to my next issue: The companions, their interactions, their stories. 
The fundamental flaw with nearly all companions is that they start off their journeys pretty much already a great person with some inner insecurity or struggle they have to overcome. They and the faction they belong to are sanitised to an insulting degree. Insulting because it is clear the writers thought the players cannot be trusted to approach difficult topics with any sort of nuance. As an example: You meet Taash, a Qunari belonging to what looks like a pirate faction, but don't worry, because Taash reassures you that unlike actual pirates, they make sure that they approach grave robbings with the appropriate amount of cultural sensibility, and that any artifact with cultural significance end up with the people it belongs to. And they of course keep in mind the power dynamic of oppressed peoples while they're doing so. So. instead of having Taash have some realisation that maybe grave robbing hurts some people and have that be part of their story, don't worry, because they never have to question anything, because all the moral quandries that come with being a pirate have been magicked away. Which makes their character that much less engaging. 

Every other topic they mention - sexuality, slavery, discrimnation - is given much the same treatment. For a city run on slavery, you barely see any slaves or the impact of slavery in Minrathous. You never experience discrimnation as an elf, even though we learn that massacring entire elven ghettos was a done thing in Thedas not too long ago. You're a mage? Well don't worry, because even though we locked you up your entire life outside of Tevinter just a decade ago, no one has any issue with you at all anymore. 
This is all very frustrating because again and again, the game demonstrates that it can be engaging and well written, and there are so many really really amazing moments, and then it gets undercut by the constant reminder that everything in this world is black and white and that you don't need to think about the consequences of the black stuff that much either. 
It really feels like the writer's room just collectively agreed on just paying the bare minimum lip service with remarks that would do well on twitter ca. 2018. Instead of even trying to get the story right, they just don't do the story at all. The story is superficially progressive while failing to engage with the people and the topics it supposedly cares about. Sure, every companion is bisexual and we have a superficially diverse cast of characters overall, but what does that matter when the game refuses to tell the stories of the people it supposedly represent? Sure there is Taash, but honestly their story was so flat and basic, it doesn't deserve a mention. The game got a lot of shit for being too "woke", but if anything, is isn't interested in exploring these topics at all.

So why would I recommend this game with all that being said?

1) The combat system is a massive improvement from what it was in Inquisition. It's fluid, fun to play, and has a decent amount of different combat styles. It is not overly challening, since the type of enemies are limited, (e.g. all dragons have basically the same move set), and thus the combat can start to feel repetitive towards the end, but playing around with different skill tree options¬¥and armor sets is still fun. 

2) The world of Thedas is stunning. They did really well in making the regions have their own distinct style and mood, and I had a lot of fun just running around and exploring every nook and cranny, especially because you get a ton of rewards in forms of chests or little secrets while doing so.

3) While I have a lot of criticism for the story telling in this game, there were some things they did supremely well. Mainly everything that didn't touch upon a sensitive issue.  The two stand outs are Solas and the Grey Wardens. Solas story is what you make of it. You see him as a villain he becomes one, you see him as an ally and he becomes that. The talks with him are the highlights of the whole game. Even beyond that, entire areas of the Fade reflect him as a person. You find and fight aspects of him, his regrets, his failures. You get fragments of the past, showing his rebellion, the choices he had to make. Hundreds of little clues about who he really is. A lot of it is optional content, which makes it even more impactful when you do find it. The Solas story is also incomparably more subtle in what it wants to say than anything else in this game. Also his VA did so so well. Bless this man.

The Grey Wardens, while not reaching the level of Solas, felt grounded and let you explore the impact of the blight in a way that felt personal. You have the choice to play as a member of any of the factions you end up working with, and I highly recommend playing as a Grey Warden, because you end up feeling much more connected to your order's struggle for surival and hope for the future. The Warden's main NPCs - the dwarven warrior and her French twink boyfriend - feel much more alive than comparable NPCs of different factions. I loved them and their story. The companion quests of Davrin, your Grey Warden companion, fits in so seemlessly with the story of the Grey Wardens that it might as well not have been a companion quest at all. Davrin really grew on me as well as a character. Great guy.

4) Manfred, the skeleton companion. I love him. He's so precious. Also Emmerich, the necromancer who he accompanies and one of your companions. Loved his story, one of the best. 

In conclusion: Whether you will have fun playing this game or not depends on the approach you take to it. The storytelling is worse than in the previous games overall, but has some stand out moments that I wouldn't want to miss as a Dragon Age fan. The gameplay is mostly fun, if a little repetetive, and the world is done well. 
I think many of the bad reviews are justified, but for those of you that are at all interested, you will probably still have a lot of fun playing.

Thanks for reading, have fun.

Dragon Age Veilguard. When you look through other reviews, what you will see is probaby some variation of "this game is woke" or "it changes the whole DA canon!". The first, i will not address, be an idiot if you want to, but the second is not really helpful in a review. I dont know anything about dragon age before DA Inquisition (one of my favorite games of all time), so this really isnt helpful to decide if a game is good or not. So: should you buy this game? 
Depends. If you like action rpgs, beautiful graphics and have a goofy sense of humor, I think you should give this one a shot. I think the writing isnt as terrible as people make it seem on here. Its not great, sure, but its not atrocious. If you turn off your brain and focus on enjoying the experience, its a good bit of fun, like a marvel movie. The characters all feel like teenagers in their banter and their awkwardness sometimes, which I find very entertaining (since, and thats something that gets lost when people say that, they are all very young. With a few exceptions, there are very little adults over like 30 in the story)

*Warning: slightly and vaguely spoilerish*

Writing an unbiased review for a game that basically concludes a series of long-beloved now tetralogy is never a breeze. Well, we are not writing here fancy critical reviews pretending to be industry-leading magazine review giants, right? 

But!

As a Dragon Age veteran and an ardent fan of the previous entries, I just want to express how grateful I am to the people, the team, every person behind this magnificent and enchanting world - the name is Thedas - Andraste bless you! So many players have trailed their self-tailored journeys to see how it all plays out in the end. Strangely as it may sound, that's what matters right now. The Veilguard might not be the closest station to the promised land, but it nicely does the job at the end of the day. That's the first reason you should try playing it. It's worth your time, believe me, my dear fellow. 

To be more specific yet not overcomplicating things, the fourth part of the series seems to be a successor of Dragon Age: Inquisition and thus might feel more spiritually distant from the first two. That's why what you get in the first place is, by all means, a gorgeous and quite dynamic environment that captivates your mind from the get-go. Optimisation and graphics are on another level, so no complaints from me, except for the uneven frame generation thing. Yeah, overall, it doesn't seem like a dark fantasy anymore, though it's not a problem at all. The only thing it means is that comparison between the first and the last games will always be an effective clickbait. Every Dragon Age has its own taste, so does the Veilguard - it tastes like a romantic epic story.

The gameplay and combat are quite pleasing. I love how they learnt the lesson from the Inquisition and moved from this "middle ground" between "action" and "tactical." Deep down, I gravely miss the DAO's tactics, but I pretty much enjoyed DAV's one, too. It's just that the progression through the maps feels quite rapid if you know how to level your character and gear properly. It also means that your low-level character will be able to defeat high-level bosses and enemies with a painful number of dodge rolls without much chemistry - it now depends on your reaction speed rather than your planning & preparation skill. That's the sad part, hehe.

As for the exploration part, it's pretty much a classic RPG experience that never fails to succeed. One thing I want to state, though, is that the progression feels so polished (which is so great on the development level) that it kind of loses its spark and negates a component of mystery and adventure. All this makes it a wonderful game for completionists, yet somehow makes the whole journey a bit linear and straightforward.

The story and the characters, the cornerstone of every Dragon Age game, are a metaphoric roller coaster for me because so many great ideas were implemented, yet they were not revealed to a tee. At its core, the main story is decent. I love how it begins, makes you feel elevated and trapped, sad and happy, even genuinely baffled sometimes. Even the longevity is fine. What I slightly dislike is how it makes these plot leaps, which create a distorted sense of reality. It feels as though they had to cut 5-10 hours of the initial main plot. It's not a big deal since the narrative is still balanced and rewarding; the pace of the narrative is, though, a problem for me. Talking about the side quests, they are just not the most exciting part of the game, for most of them share the same pattern: the attachment to a specific ally. A bit boring.

Oh, and characters! I loved them. Dragon Age never disappoints in this regard. You get to spend enough time with your sidekicks, but there is one but. Your pals are such sweethearts that you sometimes think they all pretend. Maybe it's just me and my kindhearted Rook, so I will try to create one with a more rigid mindset next time. Again, some events are a luxurious one-to-one experience: your companions share their feelings, show their different sides, talk about the pain, joy, etc. They feel real!

At the same time, some trivial events (you know, some leisure time where you visit a cafe or a bar) could be much more meaningful, not a one-minute story or tale - those kill immersion. The romance part is subjective, since I only romanced one particular character, but it ended up being the biggest letdown for me. I felt as if my Rook was in the well-secured friend zone all the time. The final scene was sort of nice, though, but they didn't even add a good old sobby happy ending part to the aftermath screen. And the worst thing is that I'm damned sure they could do it much-much better. An idea about cutting the content continues to haunt me.

Finally, what I genuinely dislike is how they almost abandoned the idea of world state import, except for some merest hints and the presence of the Inquisitor. I am well aware that this way has its limitations, but it has always been that one thing that entices the mind and makes your soul glow like the most potent red lyrium. Even if it is a faint illusion, let me live through it. Bruh.

So many opinionated thoughts! If you have read it, cheers to you. When all is said and done, all that matters is how you feel it. I choose to think that even though the Veilguard didn't live up to all my expectations, it is still an uncommonly fine game and singular Dragon Age experience. I just expected the plot and the character building to be thicker and denser - the ones the final entry of the franchise should have. Apart from that, it's still 80+ hours of wonderful role-play experience. Still not sure about the hinted sequel since such a scenario will plead for a whole separate story in the same universe (something like a Mass Effect: Andromeda thing). The time will tell!

By the way, the OST of the game is, IMHO, the least memorable among all of the Dragon Age games. That's the hard truth I spontaneously want to share.

Although the cartoonish design is weird at first, all maps offers a satisfying diversity of contexts and most of them have a great "high-fantasy" feel. The story is generally good and the core game is pretty similar to ME2 : build your team up and resolve their personal problems to maximise your chance of success when facing the final "boss(es)". At first, some characters seem bland, but they get better as the game progress. The non-binary character story is not as bad as the now infamous cutscene suggests. On that note, a few dialogs are indeed bad, but most are good and some are even great. The world-building feels not as fleshed-out compared to DAO or DAI, but it offers an interesting takes on the DA world. In particular, the Necropolis and Treviso were both pretty fun to discover. My main critic is that Veilguard feels too "literal" : previous games left some rooms for uncertainty, so that players (and characters) could express different beliefs or understandings, but this game does not (I can't say much more without spoilers). 

Finally, as someone who have played a mage in every DA games, I have to say that the combat in Veilguard is so much more dynamic and fun. Being able to switch between staff and blade/orb, which can both use different elements, makes the class really adaptable and offers the possibility for an aggressive mage play-style that I have rarely seen in RPG. The movements are generally fluid, both in combats and during exploration. On that last point, exploration feels slightly "loot-ish" and yet balanced; loot is not fundamental (but it helps a lot) and puzzle are not hard, but they are not too easy either. 

Finally, I must add that the game runs well, without any stutter or notable glitches, which is pretty rare this days. I have never encounter any crashes either.

The Dragon Age series has a special place in my heart, I have played all the games many times, saw the shows and movie, and read some of the books, yet I have come to play DA:V without any expectations due to the bad reviews I heard everywhere. I did try to remain objective, but when it comes to DA series it will always be all about my subjective opinions and feelings. 

DA:V has all the ingredients to make up a great DA story. Lovable companions who form a found family, who you have to help with all sorts of personal problems, Thedas in danger only the main character can somehow save, references to the characters and events happening across the many media DA story has touched, and of course a sprinkle of romance. 

Every DA game has brought something different. The fighting system has changed, the art style has changed, the lore was expanded, and some loose ends were tied up. DA:V is trying to tie up a lot of them. The revelations in this game aren‚Äôt always what I would expect, sometimes in a good way, and many times I have to remind myself, that it doesn‚Äôt have to be wrong just because I would have done it differently. [spoiler]I might not agree that the Crows are suddenly a happy murderous family and an elf from Arlathan forest has somehow read about a Tevinter detective, but who am I to dictate that DA history has to be static and globalization cannot touch Thedas.[/spoiler] I'm not gonna talk about the lack of important decisions being imported from previous games, because I honestly get it. I‚Äôm not happy about it, but I get it.

We‚Äôve got to talk about all the nostalgia strategies they throw at us, the model BioWare players, because gods they are not very subtle. You get a lot of references to both DA and Mass Effect series, whether it‚Äôs the visual similarities (darkspawns to husks for example), the polar decisions, the countless references, or the use of Varric‚Äôs storytelling. I love Varric, he is without a doubt my favourite character, but even I found the passages where he does the ominous foreshadowing sloppily stitched into the storyline, to make the player nostalgic about DA2. DA2 is my favourite game in the series and yet I still think it was a bit on the nose. 

To give it some credit, the game pulled one of the biggest cliches and I didn‚Äôt see it coming, which took me by surprise and left me feeling torn, I had to stop and think about whether I am mad, weirdly gratified or just sad. But exactly that is what makes the game memorable to me. That and finally seeing the characters from the whole series coming together in a big cinematic fight. DA for me is about characters and moments. DA:V has both, even though honestly it could use a bit more of the moments especially when it comes to the romantic storylines. I expected an equivalent of the singing scene from DA:I, which made me fall in love with the series, but got none. Veilguard is also very visually beautiful. I turned off bloom and the difference in just turning that setting off is INSANE. I don't even know how many screenshots I have of just the environments in this game. It just isn't a good game. I wish so badly it was a good game, but it isn't. I love the Dragon Age series, and I genuinely enjoyed aspects of DATV, and I am deeply fond of some of the characters (or at least the potential of some of the characters; even the ones I like are woefully underwritten and underwhelming). But the game is bad. It's just bad. I am not saying this in a "go woke go broke" way, culture war bullshit is stupid, I am saying it in a "no aspect of this game is worth the price tag regardless of your political opinions" way. 

The writing is clunky and doesn't fit the setting, at times seeming actively disinterested in the worldbuilding that predates the game. Why is Tevinter a queer safe haven? Remember how the Qun was accepting of trans people and Tevinter has conversion therapy blood magic?? Why are we using modern terms instead of responding to the genuinely really interesting things the previous games had to say about gender in Thedas? Why does no one react to my kossith character waltzing around Minrathous? Why can I play an elf Crow and it never even gets touched on that the Crows literally buy and groom kids, including elves, into indentured servitude as assassins, as was made evident by the very first Crow we ever meet in the series? Why does only one choice from the previous series impact this game, and WHY is that choice did you kiss Solas or not? Why can you just be casually Blighted as a game condition and you're not even a Warden? 

It's optimized so unbelievably poorly that I always have to go into task manager to edit my core priority just to avoid major audio skipping even this far after lunch, that my shaders have been verifying for near an hour now, and that, despite my PC being able to run much more complicated games with much bigger maps and much higher graphic fidelity with absolutely no issues, I keep this on low just to keep the performance manageable. Near manageable. 

The combat is...fine. I have fun with it, but it's a clear downgrade from previous games and doesn't really work on its own merits. I tried multiple difficulties in case that was a balancing problem but it just never felt engaging or fun. The companions, my favorite part of the game, are incredibly one-dimensional with questlines that seem thematically disconnected from the overarching narrative and also are really dull. The maps are kind of interesting but mostly just...disappointing. I can't believe I ever talked about the Hinterlands in Inquisition. The Hinterlands are so beautiful and full of so many quests that yeah, were busywork, but were fun or silly or narratively interesting, and meanwhile we're in LITERAL ARLATHAN and it's like um. You can line up some beams. Does that sound fun. The kids love puzzles where they line up beams, right?? None of the maps are BAD, per se, but I don't think any of them are actually good. 

There is literally one choice in the game that I thought was interesting to think about and weigh my options for in a way where my opinions and the opinions of my character mattered; the others all did not matter to me in the slightest. One. ONE. That choice didn't even have consequences in this game, and God knows we're not getting another game in the series. Of all the things that piss me off about this game, of which there are MANY, that's absolutely the worst. This is supposed to be a roleplaying game!!! Why do none of my choices matter at all? Why am I a plucky YA protagonist with no discernable personality besides "happy-go-lucky", "snarky", or "socially awkward but in an endearing way"? In Dragon Age: Origins, you could be a naive idealist, a ruthless pragmatist, a power-hungry despot in the making, a strictly principled hero, an actual CHARACTER and not an archetype. Not even a good archetype!!! I didn't make up a Rook before the game and was mad about not being able to roleplay a hyperspecific character, to be clear. I tried to genuinely engage with the worldbuilding and character options of this game and found there simply wasn't anything to work with. There was, what, one choice with consequences and the rest is all based in a "bond" and "faction strength" system that is so clearly signposted that you immediately know the "right" thing to do? Give me complexity!!! Give me problems without easy solutions! Give me characters who both despise each other for the ways in which they are inexorably opposed, and make it so there isn't an obviously right one! Give me more than "pick which companion dies teehee" one time! Give me disapproval that matters so that the approval means something! God, I remember befriending Vivienne in Inquisition and finding it so meaningful since I also had runs where she despised me. When I got tot he scene where I can punch Solas, I realized just how far I'd pushed my luck. Companions used to leave your party if you pissed them off, and now I can't even really be mean if I TRY!

Remember Fenris, who despises magic for entirely understandable reasons and can do heinous things to mages who have done nothing wrong if you don't show him enough compassion and understanding through the game? Remember how he was there with Anders, who genuinely tries to bring awareness to the plight of mages in a city that grinds the magical and the nonmagical alike to nothing at all only to decide there is no option but violent resistance? They're both wrong, and they're both right, but most importantly, they're both believable. Their experiences have shaped them into the people they are now, and your decisions as a player shape them into who they can be. That ruled. This is TWO of the eight companions you can get in DA2, and I don't even think DA2 has the most interesting interparty conflict in the series. I can tell you which has the least! It's Veilguard. Lucanis and Davrin are the closest the game attempts to it and they get over it...offscreen?? Or something? It was so half-assed I truly didn't notice, and I was romancing Lucanis. I was genuinely trying.

This game was a gift from one friend; someone whose writing I deeply admire wrote something for this. If not for those two reasons, I would not have finished it. The main thing I got out of this game were characters I could reimagine as if they were written to the quality I'd expect from the first three games, and the extra hours I spend on it -- including now, when I am STILL actively verifying the shaders as I have been the entire time I write this review, and yeah, Steam takes up a little memory but come the fuck ON, it's been an HOUR -- are driven by that affection and not by genuine enjoyment.

Perhaps one day I will be free of the curse of actually really liking the concepts of these characters so that I can go back to better games, like Dragon Age: Origins, or Dragon Age 2, or Dragon Age: Inquisition, or any of the Baldur's Gate games, or any of The Elder Scrolls games, or some random free shovelware game on here that at least you can have fun laughing at with a friend because you didn't waste anything but your time on it. 

If it goes on sale for $20 or less, I think it's worth that price tag. I genuinely would not spend more on it. To the staff that worked on this: I am sure this is a product of mismanagement and crunch and whatever other corporate nonsense happened there. I can see where there is love and passion in places. The problem is that only serves to highlight the rest of it, and the rest fucking blows.

It's a bit too mid overall, a bit too expensive and not Dragon Age enough to warrant the name or what one would expect from picking up the title. If I could give a mixed review, I would. Someone will balance this one with a positive one.

I also feel some sources, including Steam tags, claiming it's a CRPG are a bit misleading. If you're looking for your next CRPG, look elsewhere, this is as ARPG as DA has ever been, and you don't have the type of party control I'd expect from the former tag.

The Good:
When scenes, dialogue and lore are good, they're quite good.

Rogue is fun to play. There's not too many combos you can string together, but they're well animated and fun to execute.

The vibes are there in maps.

The companions have banter, and it mostly lands. Their side quests delve into their character well enough, and the player gets to connect with them well enough.

The Bad:
Warrior (Fighter?) and Mage just feel like they have separate attacks rather than anything I'd call  combos. Some specials are fun, but I'm glad I tried Rogue first, because I would be a lot harsher on the combat if I had not.

When the writing, dialogue and lore are bad, they're quite bad. It takes too long for the story to pick up, and when it does it just can't balance out the slog from before.

The choices aren't really choices most of the time, they're quite limited flavour text. The ones that matter felt a bit too contrived for me, or a bit too obvious as to what is the optimal decision. I don't say optimal as a binary or "good" and "bad", because you can't be evil in this game, I quite literally mean the decision that is more successful and saves more characters. (except if you don't wanna off someone in the party, that is)

A lot of interesting themes are tackled, but they're not tackled well quite often. It's a very superficial exploration of them, which is insufficient at best and a bit insulting at worst. This is most noticeable when talking to companions.  

Puzzles are abundant and clear as day. They feel like padding. I'd rather they just weren't in the game.

While the vibes are there, you don't really get to explore a lot of cool looking parts in the maps. There's pretty minimal interaction with the NPCs inside them.

The mid:
Combat overall is pretty simple compared to other hack and slash games. You can't string very many combos, and they all serve the same purpose, a.k.a deal damage and stun lock. There are some fun things you can do with i frames on skills and some skills do look like combos, but it doesn't quite work well enough to compete with similar action titles. You're limited to 3 skills, so it's not like you're getting the CRPG experience either.

While decent in their personal quests, companions are just kinda mid when involved in the main plot.

I don't normally post reviews and when I do, they're usually memey and positive. But just this once, I'll break that silence and post my first negative one. 

I've been a long time fan of the Dragon Age series. It's been one of my favourites since I first played Origins. I even enjoyed DA2, where others hated it or consider it the worst in the series. It's actually my favourite! Inquisition is a close second for me. 

Dragon Age the Veilguard does not exist in my canon. This game is absolute garbage. Don't get me wrong. It's not the politics of the game that make it trash, it goes far beyond that. This game is a layered *mess* for multiple reasons, and the politics are only one small part. 

The good: 
I enjoy the gameplay itself. The way the combat plays is not that bad. At first, I disliked it because I was expecting the classic combat style we saw in Origins and that was reprised for Inquisition. It leans into tactical play (which is not my strong suit admittedly) and here, we lean even further into how I feel DA2 played. Ultimately, the combinations are satisfying, it feels punchy enough and I actually play on a higher difficulty than I normally would for a DA game. 

The bad: 
- The camera is jank. Switching from combat to non-combat is weird as hell and it resets the camera in the oddest manner. Worse, if you're in an enclosed space, it becomes a jittery mess that makes me sick to even look at. I had to turn camera shake to 0% just to deal with it. It's awful. 

- The lore has been fucked with pretty hard. I could go on and on about it, but essentially, there's a fair amount of established lore that's just been revised, interpreted very strangely or nay-sayed by characters for no good discernible reason. The biggest issue with this is that it's a big slap in the face of old DA lovers like myself. We're essentially being told 'that thing you loved? It's shit so you should feel like a bad person for liking it'. That's how it feels, at least. 

- They've removed player agency. Dragon Age was about playing a character who was either good or morally grey, who wanted to save the world (or city, for DA2). You could be an asshole to people sometimes, you could choose to kick companions from your party, you could have intermittent conversations with them whenever you liked AND you could also choose to NOT recruit some. For some unknown reason they've taken these options away. I HAVE to recruit every available companion. I CANNOT kick them from my party anymore. Yes, I can choose not to engage with some, but I no longer have the choice to leave them out of MY story at all. This is very anti-Dragon Age to me. 

- Leading on from this one, Taash is an issue everyone has mentioned already. I think things here are more nuanced than most people really care to mention so I will attempt to unpack it at greater length. Firstly, I don't have an issue with a character being non-binary, let alone a person. Disliking a character who -happens- to be non-binary does not make me a bigot no matter what people will tell me. What I dislike about the character is not their identity, it's how poorly it was written and represented. Rather than finding a way to naturally incorporate their identity struggles into the world as it is, the writers chose to be incredibly on-the-nose about it and lore-breaking. My immersion is ruined and that's one of the reasons I take issue with the character. Rather than using 'non-binary' as the language, just find another way to describe it. You don't even have to -give- it a name or label and in fact, if you do that, I think more people will be able to identify widely with the character as a whole. Those who simply don't feel they belong can identify with the character, and not just those who are non-binary. 

To continue from that point, Taash also uses pretty misogynistic language and I feel as if this is really poorly done as well. I understand that the point is trying to convey that this character has an issue with womanhood in themselves and is grappling with that, but the way they speak about womanhood as a whole is incredibly toxic and perpetuates some awful anti-women culture and rhetoric that is already far too prevalent in video games. When women are constantly ridiculed, sexually harassed and given death or r*pe threats online for just participating in gaming communities (I have personally experienced much of this), this is not something that needs to be written in this way. You can do it another way. We can easily understand what's going on when Taash expresses how much they hate dresses or skirts, and how they don't identify with other concepts relating to femininity without the emphasis on 'how awful it is to be a woman'. I happen to like being a woman, thank you very much. In essence, it feels very out of touch. 

Further to that, the way they treat their mother is horrific. This woman has been raised within a very rigid society that dictates who does what for the -rest of their lives-. She broke away from that to protect her child, which already shows a very open mind for someone who was raised within such a structured life. Why, then, do the dialogue options offered not allow us to truly bridge the gap between the parent and child? We can only realistically look like an asshole for agreeing with Taash--in my opinion, at least, because I sympathise with a woman who has left EVERYTHING behind to raise her child safely and is trying to understand said child as best she can in the ways she knows how--or we can look like an asshole for agreeing with the mother, because if you don't agree with Taash you're a dickhead. Why are those my only real options? Can I not encourage Taash to be more understanding and encourage their mother to recognise that without the Qun's structure and ideals, her child has developed very differently? 

There is so much wrong with the way this character was written that they come across feeling like the epitome of virtue signalling and it's uncomfortable to be around. Yes, I do not have to engage with this character but I do HAVE to recruit them. Even if I don't want to. 

- All of which leads into my next point. Where is my personality? I can no longer choose how nice or mean to be. Every aggressive or stoic option of dialogue available to me makes me the nicest and gentlest person in Thedas. I can no longer have my own opinions on things like blood magic (beforehand, you could say you either approved or disapproved of it) and now the game has just decided much of it for me. I can no longer BE the morally grey, gritty person I enjoyed playing back in the day. I'm just a sanitised, rainbow happy nice person who wants everyone to get along. There's no interpersonal conflict anymore and you rarely do things that make your companions -disapprove- of you. I hate it. I miss the days where I could choose things for myself. Player choice was always a big thing for Dragon Age and they've removed it pretty much completely. If I wanted to play an RPG where I play as Geralt or some other pre-written character, I'd have played one of those games. This is not what is expected of a Bioware game. At all. 

- The tone is completely off. I understand that comes primarily from writing and rewriting issues due to development changes. I won't harp on about it too much but the gritty, dark, moody world I love and know has been reduced to ":DDDDD omg the elven gods are running around let's take them down guys! <insert marvel one-liner here for zany effect>". Enough said, really.

Everything that drew people to this series - the dark fantasy, the grey morality, the choices and consequences. the ROLE PLAYING - they're all gone, and what is left is a sanitised piece of bargain bin shit that attempts to draw people in with flashy fight scenes and quippy dialogue.
